content: this case long waited much requested dug up the
footage the other day finally here it is my take on futuristic tiles we begin as
always with our foundations for this design we have yet another set of
measurements and here they are the walls will be made from single corrugated
cardboard so cut some strips that are 3/4 of an inch wide and from those
strips you can chop your wall segments for this tutorial let's build a single
side wall tile hot glue the wall to the side of your foundation
and then apply corrugation cladding next let's take some chipboard and cut
some strips that are 1/2 inch wide and quarter inch wide chop these strips into
small pieces alternating between straight cuts and slanted cuts these
will be the panels on the wall hot glue them to the wall big ones on the outside
small ones on the inside whenever you attach a slanted piece
complement it with another one going the other way and leave a gap somewhere
along the wall now select your favorite neutral gray
I'm using slate gray and base all of the tile with it except for the surface that
will be immediately beneath the game spaces for that one surface paint it's
solid black now in the gaps you left in your wall panels paint a stripe of color
I used yellow whatever you choose make sure it's a solid bold color after
that's dry we're going to wash the entire tile with black this is a pretty
thin wash our goal is really just to add some grit to that flat gray
after that dries use plain white and Nick at the edges of all the wall panels
this doesn't take as long as you might think it would then take a black sharpie
and apply four dots per panel at each of the four corners these are like the
rivets or the screws this is a plastic mesh that's used for some kind of sewing
I'm not sure what I think it's called cross stitching anyway you can get it at
any crafting store the sheet is about one square foot and it was only sixty
cents so we're talking very very cheap I'm going to measure a little under one
and a quarter inches and find the nearest row rounding down and cut a
strip of this mesh this is slick plastic so first I'm going
to base it with a neutral color I was running low on white paint so I'm using
gray here but a matte acrylic paint will do the job after it dries then we apply
our metallic silver color now from this strip we can chop the pieces that we
need for the single wall there will be two squares and two rectangles to apply
them to the tile just apply a small dab of hot glue at each of the four corners
on the mesh on the underside it'll spread out and slightly use around the
mesh when you apply it but it really doesn't show up very much
before we go to the game table here's two additional thoughts you may be
thinking you want to cover the gaps between the spaces like this if you want
to go for it but that's a lot of work and I was happy enough with how they
looked so I didn't bother also you might be thinking that the wall panels are too
much effort so here's actually how I built these tiles in the first place
when I was experimenting the wall is double corrugated cardboard so you'll
need to adjust your foundation size appropriately but it's a double
corrugated cardboard with cladding and then I simply draw the panels on with a
fine point sharpie instead of the the chipboard pieces this will reduce your
crafting time by about two-thirds which is pretty massive I've heard people
mention Space Hulk I had never heard of it I guess it takes place on a derelict
spaceship and these tiles would certainly fit the bill they do kind of
have a 40k esque gothic feel to them as opposed to like a slick polished like a
Star Trek type of feel now think about the math for a sec single corrugated
cardboard is 1/8 inch thick and chipboard is 1/16 of an inch thick so
when you add it all up our walls have ended up being our usual quarter inch
thick and the tiles are a total of two and a half inches in size you can back
calculate this to come up with the size of the foundations that I showed you
earlier so here's a metal door that we did back in episode 31 and you can see
that it fits well in fact all of the wall clip scenery that you've built from
this channel is compatible with these tiles now I don't play much sci-fi and I
probably won't be revisiting these any time soon so here's a freebie right now
this is how I made those laser containment barriers that you see this
is a new kind of clip it clips on to the floor instead of the wall take some
toothpicks and chop them down to a length of one and thirteen sixteenths of
an inch base them in plain white take some thin
cardstock and cut a 1 inch by 2 inch rectangle fold it lengthwise twice such
that it fits snugly around the tile as shown
cut two small bits of chipboard about a quarter inch wide and a half inch long
paint those and the clip itself with metallic silver paint the laser beams
with a neon color you'll probably need to do several coats later on but those
can be done in place so just do the first coat for now now simply hot glue
both beams to one of the chipboard mounts
and then do the same on the other side lastly hot glue both mounts to the clip
itself there you have it piece of cake that is
a floor clip I am wile Locke thank you for joining me
